Situation1: They review project timelines casually, ensuring tasks are generally progressing.
Expectation2: Participate in civic life by staying informed, voting, and giving constructive feedback
Situation2: A ballot measure affecting their block closes in two hours at the nearby polling place.
Story: I sat at my desk, blueprints spread out before me, the hum of the office a familiar background. As an architect, I was expected to keep projects on track, and today I was reviewing timelines for the new community center. I glanced at the clock, noting that tasks were moving along, but I hadn’t double-checked the contractor’s latest updates. I told myself I’d get to it soon. Then my phone buzzed—a reminder that the polling place down the street would close in two hours. There was a ballot measure up for vote, one that could change the zoning laws on my own block. As a citizen, I knew I should go, cast my vote, maybe even talk to neighbors about the impact. But if I left now, I’d lose precious time on the project, and my team was counting on me to keep things moving. My mind raced, torn between my duty to my profession and my responsibility to my community, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing in as the minutes ticked by.
